docs.lead_paragraph: The Working column on April 25, about personal questions in job interviews, misstated the legal treatment of interview questions involving a potential employee's pregnancy or child-bearing plans. Under Federal law, a company cannot use the answers to such questions in a decision on hiring, but it is not prohibited from asking them. The courts, however, usually regard such questions as evidence that pregnancy was a factor in refusing to hire someone, according to a lawyer at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The column also misstated the treatment of pregnancy in disability law. Under the Americans With Disabilities Act, normal pregnancy is not a protected disability.

docs.lead_paragraph: Manhattan Theater Club MONDAY -- The Manhattan Theater Club will hold its annual spring gala at the New York Hilton. Among those scheduled to perform excerpts from the Broadway shows they star in are Bernadette Peters and Tom Wopat, from ''Annie Get Your Gun''; Valarie Pettiford and Jane Lanier, ''Fosse,'' and Kristin Chenoweth, ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' The event will benefit the theater organization, which develops new plays and offers subsidized tickets and playwriting workshops to schoolchildren. Drinks at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner and the show. Tickets, $500, from (212) 399-3000, ext. 146. For Summer Campers WEDNESDAY -- The Coalition for the Homeless will hold a reception from 7 to 9 P.M. at F. A. O. Schwarz, Fifth Avenue at 58th Street. Proceeds will help to send homeless children to summer sleep-aways at Camp Homeward Bound in Harriman State Park in Harriman, N.Y. The event will include arts and crafts, face painting, music, refreshments and a visit from Cookie Monster. Tickets, $100, or $50 for children under 14, from (212) 964-5900, ext. 118.

docs.lead_paragraph: They were pioneers as American soccer players, star defenders on teams that won a world championship in 1991 and an Olympic gold medal in 1996, and now they are plowing new cultural ground as soccer moms. Last December, facing six months on the road in preparation for next month's Women's World Cup, residing at a training camp in Orlando, Fla., and barnstorming the United States and Portugal to play tuneup games, Joy Fawcett and Carla Overbeck negotiated to have the United States soccer federation pay for a nanny to accompany the team and to help care for their young children.

headline.main: U.S. National Team Has Redefined 'Soccer Mom'
